question: Black eye is a type of -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s. narayan reddy; 28th edition; Pg. no. 107 Black eye is the most common example for ectopic bruising or percolated contusion.

question: One of the following is the first enzyme to be released at the site of wound?
exp: Ref - Krishan Vij textbook of forensic medicine and toxicology 5e pg - 202

question: Organs first to be injured in blast -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no. 138 Tympanic membrane rupture most commonly with hemorrhage in the ear. Blast lung is the other most common injury.

question: Chocking is constricting device within the barrel at the muzzle end of -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no 122 The choke bore present in a shot gun, the distal 7-10 cm of the barrel is narrow. There are some shotguns which have a small poion of their bore near the muzzle end rifled, which are called "paradox gun".

question: In case of hanging neck ligature marks are example of -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology - Dr k. s. narayan reddy; 28th edition; Pg no. 105 Also called crushing or friction abrasion. The are caused by crushing of superficial layer of epidermis & are associated with bruise of the surrounding area. occurs when movement of instrument is around 90deg to the skin. hanging, strangulation, teeth bite marks are examples.

question: Feature that differentiates true from aificial bruise
exp: contusion: not well defined, diffuse, and irregular margins Aificial bruise: well defined with regular margins. Ref: FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY DR PC IGNATIUS THIRD EDITION PAGE 120

question: Stretch laceration is seen in
exp: Stretch laceration These lacerations occur from over stretching of the skin and soft tissues due to heavy forceful impact exercising a localised pressure. Stretching of tissues can occur in run over by a motor vehicle. Ref: FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY Dr PC IGNATIUS THIRD EDITION PAGE 121
opd: Impact by sharp objects with heavy base

question: Di collar or grease collar is seen in -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no 131 A di collar is seen in firearm entry wound, it is seen as narrow ring of skin, lining the defect & is sharply outlined. This results from the removal of substances from the bullet as it passes through the skin, i. e bullet lubrication, gun oil from the interior of the barrel, lead from the surface of bullet, barrel debris etc.

question: 'Fracture-ala signature' or signature fracture is -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine &toxicology Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no. 140. Depressed fractures produced by local deformation of skull, caused by a heavy weapon with small striking surface. These are also called FRACTURE A LA SIGNATURE (SIGNATURE FRACTURE)

question: Feature which differentiates true from aificial bruise is -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s. narayan; 28 th edition Pg. no. 110 Table 8-3 Shape of true bruise is usually round while that of aificial bruise is irregular. Erythema & swelling seen in the surrounding area in case of aificial bruise not in true bruise. In true bruise erythema and swelling is seen in the site.

question: Percolating of blood to the lateral aspect of head behind the ear is indicative of
exp: Black eye( Raccoon's sign) in case of anterior cranial fossa fracture, extravasation of blood around the eye and in the periorbital tissue can be observed. It is due to percolation of blood to the periorbital tissue. This is called black eye. Battle's sign in case of middle cranial fossa fracture, there may be percolation of blood to the lateral aspect of head behind the dark which is called Battle's sign Cullen's sign Ectopic bruise around umbilicus in extraperitoneal or intra abdominal bleed or rupture ectopic pregnancy or acute pancreatitis. Grey -Turner's sign Ectopic bruise at flank in retroperitoneal hemorrhage. Ref: FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY Dr PC IGNATIUS THIRD EDITION PAGE 117

question: In a larger bruise, the colour changes begins at:
exp: In a larger bruise, the colour change stas from periphery (healing of contusion) The contusion regains its normal colour in 1-2 weeks.

question: 'Lucid Interval' may be seen in -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no. 144& 266 Lucid interval is seen in insanity during which all the symptoms of insanity disappear completely. It is also seen in extra dural hemorrhage, subdural haemorrhage (if there is lucid interval this may be longer than average of 4 hours in extradural hemorrhage.)

question: Chop wound is also known as -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine &toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; pg. no. 113; 28th edition; They are deep gaping wounds caused by a blow with the sharp cutting edge of a fairly heavy weapon. Hence also called slash wound.

question: The assessment and differentiation of entry wound and exit wound is difficult during postmoem examination of a case of death due to bullet injury due to surgical alterations. This phenomenon is known as -
exp: It is called Kennedy phenomenon after J. F. Kennedy. This phenomenon is a surgical intervention of fire arm wound resulting in an aifact and hence making the wound difficult to interpret during autopsy as happened in the case of 35th president of the US, John. F. Kennedy's assassination in 1963. Ref: NCBI. org

question: Counter coup injury seen in when -
exp: the synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no. 143 Mechanism of contrecoup injury when a moving head is suddenly decelerated by hitting a firm surface.
opc: Fall of heavy object on head

question: Antemoem abrasions can be confused with -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology - Dr k. s. narayan reddy; 28th edition; Pg no. 106 Erosion of skin produced by ants & excoriation of skin by excreta are differential diagnosis of antemoem abrasion. ants produce brown linear erosion with irregular margins of superficial layers of skin. mostly found in mucocutaneous junction, about the eyelids, nostrils, mouth and genitalia, moist folds of skin. vital reaction is not seen.

question: Keyhole bullet entry is a feature of -
exp: the synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no 134 A ricochet bullet is one in which before striking the object aimed at, strikes some intervening object first then after rebounding from these hits the object. Sometimes a bullet may strike an object & tumble & hit the body side on, producing an elongated wound of entrance like a keyhole.

question: Graze is a form of:
exp: Graze/ Brush burn/ gravel rash: Most common type of abrasion Due to violent rubbing of skin on rough surface ( eg. dragging over road). Seen in road traffic accidents

question: Sparrow foot marks are seen in?
exp: the synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no. 150 Multiple punctate lacerations of the face are produced due to the shattering of the wind screen glass into multiple small fragments with relatively blunt edges (SPARROW FOOT MARKS).

question: Flaying is seen in
exp: Avulsion It is a lacerated wound that is produced by a tangential force at an acute angle( shearing force). A poion of skin with soft tissues is found detached. This type of laceration usually occurs in traffic accidents. This happens when a heavy weight produces a shearing and rotatory force, like a lorry wheel passes over a limb. This is called flaying. ref: FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY Dr PC IGNATIUS THIRD EDITION PAGE NO 121

question: Concealed puncture wounds are seen over the following regions except
exp: CONCEALED PUNCTURED WOUNDS: Puncture wounds on the concealed pas of body Sites: Nostrils, fontanelles, inner canthus of eyes, axilla, vagina, rectum and the nape of the neck. Fatal penetrating injuries without leaving any visible external marks or bleeding. are caused by cylinderical weapons/instruments eg. ice pics etc

question: Hu Is defined under section
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no. 154; Hu means bodily pain, disease or infirmity caused to any person (S. 319, I. P. C.)

question: A man was found with suicidal shot on right temple. The gun was in his right hand. The skull was burst open. There was charring and cherry red coloration in the track inside. What can be said about shot -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no 130 Suicidal shots are usually contact shot, the impact will be more, wound larger, margins contused & eveed.
opb: Close shot at a distance of one foot from hand

question: Antemoem and postmoem wounds could be differentiated by all, except -
exp: the synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28 th edition; Pg. no. 106 By sharp edges we can not differentiate between antemoem & postmoem wound. All the other options are applicable.

question: Friction burn on the skin indicates that
exp: Friction burn: Extensive, superficial, reddened excoriated area minimal or no linear mark Occurs when the skin is covered by clothing or the person is dragged on smooth surface (eg. on a marble floor) Brush burn: Graze abrasion involving wider area such as the back, caused by violent rubbing against a surface, as in dragging along over the ground. In an abrasion caused by a tangential force, the direction of the force can be determined by epidermal tags.
opd: Pointed object passing across the skin

question: In a patient of unilateral loss of vision, the patient had injury to opposite eye leading to corneal opacification. The patient was operated by corneal grafting, he could see clearly again with one eye. The injury is said to be -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no. 155; There is permanent privation (loss) of sight of one eye, therefore its a grievous hu.

question: Presence of spiral grooves in the barrel of weapon is referred to as -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no 123 & 124 The bore is cut internally with number of shallow, spiral " grooves" varying from two to more than twenty, the most common being six, which run parallel to each other but twisted spirally, from breech to muzzle. The groove are called rifling and the projecting ridges between these grooves are called "lands".

question: Gutter fracture of skull results from
exp: Gutter fractures: They are formed when pa of the thickness of the bone is removed so as to form a gutter e. g. oblique bullet wound. Ref - Krishnan Vij 5th edition pg 156, 275

question: Back spattering is -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no. 130 Back spattering is seen in case of contact shot where there is sucking in of blood, hair, fragments of tissues & cloth fibers several cm. Back inside the barrel.
opa: The negative pressure in the barrel, sucking blood and tissues
opc: Gushing of blood from the exit gunshot wound
opd: Gushing of blood due to aerial bleed

question: In run-over accidents the following type of laceration is commonly seen:
exp: In run over accidents, avulsion is seen AVULSION: - It is produced by shearing force delivered at tangential angle to tear off a poion of traumatized skin surface from their attachment. - In run over accidents, avulsion / flaying/ flapping is seen in which flap laid tells us about the direction of force. Split laceration: It occurs due to crushing of the skin in between two hard objects. Stretch laceration: It is due to over stretching of skin. It is seen in case of open fracture. Tear laceration: tearing (of skin or subcutaeus tissue) can occur due to localized impact by some hard and irregular object Cut lacerations: it can occur by a heavy sharp edged weapon which causes a deep and wide cut over the body tissues.

question: Linear abrasion is the other name for
exp: Linear abrasion (scratch abrasion) Linear abrasions are produced by horizontal or tangential movements of the tip of a pointed object like thorn, nail, tip of pointed knife, pin, etc. In this type of abrasion, the width is minimal. There may be heaping of the denuded cuticle at one end and from this, the direction of application of force and the relative position of the victim and assailant can be found out. Ref: FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY Dr PC IGNATIUS THIRD EDITION PAGE 112

question: Brown color of contusion is true is due to -
exp: the synopsis for forensic medicine & toxicology. Dr. ks. narayan reddy, 28th edition. Pg no. 108 Colour of the bruise indicates the age of bruise, the colour change is due to the breaking down of hemoglobin into haemosiderin, haematoidin and bilirubin by the action of enzymes. At first: red Few hours to 3 days: blue 4th day: bluish black to brown (hemosiderin ) 5-6th day: greenish (haematoidin ) 7-12th day: yellow (bilirubin ) 2 weeks: normal

question: A circular bullet wound, erythema seen around the margin, blackening & tattooing present. What is the range
exp: * Presence of erythema, blackening & tattooing around the wound indicates that it is close shot. Ref:- Essentials of Forensic medicine Dr KS narayana Reddy 33th Edition; Pg num:- 216

question: Puppe's rule deals with -
exp: Ref: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no. 131 Puppet's rule is applicable to any multiple blunt force causing skull fractures. The test depends on the observation of the fracture lines either when they intersect each other or when they intersect a cratered lesion, so that one can determine which crack or defect have been formed first.

question: During examination in injury, hair bulbs are crushed. The probable type of wound is
exp: HAIR BULBS ARE CRUSHED IN LACERATION Laceration - is the tearing of skin or muscles or mucous membrane caused by a shearing or a crushing force, and produced by application of a blunt force to a broad area of the body. - If the blunt force produces extensive bruising and laceration of deeper tissue, it is called crush injury.

question: Characteristic of incised wound are all except -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; Pg. no. 112 As the vessels are cut cleanly, bleeding is more. spuing of blood occurs if an aery is cut.
opa: Length of wound not correlated with weapon

question: "Molotov cocktail" is -
exp: It is a incendiary bomb, also called petrol bomb, bottle bomb, poor man's grenade. It is used by street criminals, protesters, rioters. Ref: Wikipedia.

question: Toure in which legs or thighs are tied with bamboo and the tourer presses on the two sides of the clamp to cause pain is caused -
exp: This method is called chepuwa, it is a Bhutanese technique of toure, causing severe pain to the victim. Ref: Dogra and Rudra Lyon's Medical Jurisprudence and Toxicology 11th edition page 693

question: Which of the following is false regarding this condition?
exp: The CT image image shown above is of Extra Dural Hemorrhage It is due to rupture of middle meningeal aeries whereas SDH is due to rupture of bridging or communicating veins
opd: Rupture of bridging or communicating veins

question: "Motor cyclist" fracture among the following
exp: Hinge' fracture (Motorcyclist fracture) occurs when the linear fracture passes across the middle cranial fossa, separating the skull base into 2 halves, and may be caused by a heavy blow to the side of the head (e. g. in motorcycle accidents). Ref - Krishnan Vij 5th edition pg 300
opa: Hinge fracture of base of skull
opb: Ring fracture of base of skull

question: Following is false regarding the bullet entry wound in skull -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no 132 As the bone fragments have to pass through the dura before entering the brain, lacerations are usually irregular & involve leptomeninges. Pieces of bone from the wound of entry are often driven into cranial cavity & may establish the bullet track.
opa: Punched in hole in outer table
opc: No pieces of bone are present in the bullet track
opd: Wound is funnel shaped with the funnel opening in the direction in which the bullet is travelling

question: Scab or crust of abrasion appears brown in:
exp: Fresh Raw & Reddish 2 - 24 hours Reddish scab (lymph, blood dries up) 2 - 3 days Reddish brown scab 4 - 5 days Brown scab 6- 7 days Scab falls off. Remember the mnemonic RRRBBB

question: In tandembullet, the number of bullets fired is?
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pgbuller 35: The number of bullet fired is 2. when it is fired the second may go off carrying the lodged bullet with it & both bullet may enter the body through same entrance wound.

question: Motorcyclist fracture among the following is -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no. 151. At autopsy the base of the skull is seen divided into 2 halves each moving independently of each other like a hinge, it is called motor cyclist's fracture.
opc: Comminuted fracture of vault of skull
opd: Fracture base of skull into anterior & posterior halves

question: Which of the following bullets leaves a visible mark in path so that a person can see it -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no. 126 Tracer bullet leaves a mark or trace while in fight due to which the gunner can observe the strike of shot.

question: Avulsion is a type of:
exp: Avulsion is a type of laceration. Both "Avulsion" and "stretch laceration" have similar mechanism of formation. i. e. overstretching, but the amount of force involved is much more in Avulsion. Stretch laceration: Force is applied in such a manner that there is overstretching of the skin resulting in a flap. Eg. Glancing kick by a foot Avulsion (Shearing laceration): Here also there is overstretching of skin like in stretch laceration but the force involved is much more severe and the area involved is comparatively larger. There is separation of the skin from the underlying tissues over a relatively large area that is also called FLAYING. This is characteristic of run over accidents. The below image shows Flaying:

question: Characteristic amnesia of post traumatic brain injury
exp: Anterograde amnesia is characteristically seen in post traumatic brain injury Amnesia following head injuries is common and mostly associated with concussion. Concussion: due to head injury a state of temporary unconsciousness which comes on immediately after injury, is always followed by amnesia and recovers spontaneously The memory of distant events returns before the memory of recent events. Post-traumatic amnesia can range from minutes to days, and its duration is propoional to the severity of the injury Permanent retrograde amnesia can vary from a time of seconds up to seven days Retrograde amnesia can also occur in injuries in which consciousness is not lost.

question: Incised looking laceration is seen in all except -
exp: the synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s. narayan reddy, 28th edition; Pg. no. 110 Incised like or incised looking wounds: laceration produced without excessive skin crushing, may have relatively sharp margin. Blunt force on areas where the skin is close to bone, and subcutaneous tissue are scanty, may produce a wound which by linear splitting of the tissues, may look like incised wound. the sites ate the scalp, eyebrows, cheekbone, lower jaw, iliac crest, perineum, and shin. A wound produced by a fall on the knee or elbow with the limb flexed and by a broken glass or sharp stone also looks like incised wound. On chest there is more muscle tone & comparatively greater subcutaneous fat, so incised looking lacerations are less common on chest. Also refer page no. 119 (table 8-5 )

question: "Ewing's postulates" refer to?
exp: Ewings postulates - these suggest the occurrence of tumour after infliction of trauma. 1. Previous integrity of tissues should be proved2. There should be definite, adequate and recurrent trauma. 3. Definite time interval between trauma and tumour4. Disease must develop at the exact site of trauma5. Nature of tumour must be proved histologically Only if the above five postulates are satisfied, only then we can say that tumour has resulted because of trauma.

question: Injury by Lathi -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology - Dr. k. s narayan reddy Pg no. 106; 28th edition; Contusion (Bruises) it is the effusion of blood into tissues, due to rupture of blood vessels and due to blunt violence. Lathi injury is a injury caused by blunt force. in contusion there is painful swelling and crushing or tearing of the subcutaneous tissue, usually without destruction of the skin.

question: Lacerated wound looks like incised wound over -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s. narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no. 110 Scalp is the most appropriate answer as the skin is close to bone and subcutaneous tissues are scanty, therefore produces a incised like wound.

question: Blue colour of bruise is due to
exp: Age of contusion Time since injury Color change First day red(Hb) 2-3 days blue(deoxy. Hb) 4-5 days bluish black/brown(hemosiderin) 5-6 days greenish(hematoidin) 7-10 days yellow(bilirubin) By 14 days normal Ref: FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY DR PC IGNATIUS THIRD EDITION PAGE 118

question: Brown colour of contusion is due to
exp: age of contusion Time since injury Color change First day red(hemoglobin) 2-3 days blue (deoxy. Hb) 4-5 days bluish black/brown(hemosiderin) 5-6 days greenish(hematoidin) 7-10days yellow(bilirubin) By 14 days normal ref: FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY Dr PC IGNATIUS THIRD EDITION PAGE 118

question: Feature of ante moem drowning is
exp: Cadaveric spasm Weed paicles, twigs, leaves, etc may be seen firmly grasped in hands due to cadaveric spasm. This indicates that the person was alive when entered the water and was struggling. Cadaveric spasm with weed paicles in hand can be taken as a definite ante-moem sign of drowning. Ref: FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY Dr PC IGNATIUS THIRD EDITION PAGE 264
opd: Grass and weeds grasped in hand

question: Ectopic bruise is most commonly seen in -
exp: the synopsis for forensic medicine & toxicology, Dr. k. s. narayan reddy, 28th edition Page no. 107 Bruises do not always appear on the site of impact. blood escaping from deep torn vessels may be prevented from reaching the skin at the point of impact because the facial plane arrangements at the injured area. the bruise may appear at a relatively distant place, where the fascial pattern permits it to reach the surface ( ECTOPIC BRUISING OR PERCOLATED CONTUSION ). eg. - 1) spectacle hematoma; black eye ( hemorrhage in the soft tissue around the eyes & in the eyelids (a) punch in the eye (direct ), (b) blunt impact to the forehead, the blood gravitating downward over supra orbital bridge, (c) fracture of the floor of the anterior fossa of the skull. 2) in fracture of jaw, bruice appear in the neck. 3) a bruise behind the ear may indicate a basal fracture, rather than a direct blow behind the ear ( battle 's sign) 4)in fracture of pelvis, a bruise appear on the thigh. 5)in fracture of femur a bruise appear on the outer side of the lower pa of the thigh. 6) a kick on the calf of the leg may appear as a bruise around the ankle. Hence it can be said that the ectopic bruising are most commonly seen in eyes.

question: Kennedy phenomenon is seen in -
exp: Kennedy phenomenon is seen in a gun shot injury. In reference to 35th American president J. F Kennedy who died of gun shot, during the autopsy it was difficult to differentiate the entry wound & exit wound due to surgical alterations. Ref: NCBI. org

question: Incised wound which is not a feature -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s. narayan reddy; 28th edition; Pg. no. 112; Option A, B, D are correct about an incised wound however the statement D which states that the margin is invereted is wrong. In an incised wound margins are clean cut, well defined & usually EVEED.
opb: Width is more than the thickness of the blade
opd: Hesitation cuts are seen in suicidal attempt

question: Not a pa of firearm -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28 edition; Pg no. 122, 124, 125 Refer the diagrams.

question: False about lacerated wound is:
exp: Laceration - is the tearing of skin or muscles or mucous membrane caused by a shearing or a crushing force, and produced by application of a blunt force to a broad area of the body. - If the blunt force produces extensive bruising and laceration of deeper tissue, it is called crush injury. Features: Margins -Ragged, irregular and uneven Site -most commonly over bony prominences Bruising and abrasion - is seen around the margin Hair bulbs - are crushed Hemorrhage - is less, because the aeries are crushed and torn irregularly, they retract and blood clots readily

question: Ladder tears are seen in
exp: Horizontal tears of the aoic intima that occur in deceleration injuries which are linked to compression by the anterior face of the veebral column Ref: medical dictionary

question: Lathi can cause all of the following injuries, except:
exp: Lathi is a blunt weapon. It cannot produce incised wound, which is a sharp force injury. Blunt force injuries: Abrasion, Contusion, Laceration & Fracture. Sharp force: Incised wound (light cutting weapon), chop wound (heavy cutting weapon) & Stab (pointed weapon).

question: Hesitation cuts are seen in:
exp: Hesitation cuts are: - suicidal or self inflicted wounds - are multiple, superficial, parallel - are present on accessible pas of body. Defense wounds are characteristic of homicide but are not mandatory.

question: Bullet entry wound, for bullet entering at acute angle is identified by what shape of abrasion collar -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no 132; If bullet strikes at right angle abrasion collar is circular & uniform, if acute angle the abrasion collar will be oval due to increased width on one one side.

question: In a firearm injury, there is burning, blacking, tattooing around the wound, along with cherry red colour of the surrounding tissues and is cruciate in shape, the injury is -
exp: the synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no 130 The description of the above injury matches that of a contact shot.

question: FG, FFG, FFFG.... used to describe -
exp: the synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; Pg. no. 125; Black powder is designated as FG, FFG, FFFGetc depending on the size of grains. The more number of F the finer are the grains & faster is the burning.

question: Commonest organ to be injured in primary blast injuries is -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no. 138. Lungs show sub pleural patchy hemorrhage in the ear, often in the line of ribs, rupture of alveolar septa & bullae at the margins. Desquamated alveolar & bronchial epithelium is seen lying free. This causes reactive pulmonary edema & blood stained froth is found in air passages & later bronchopneumonia. this is called blast lung.

question: A rickshaw tyre passed on a 8 years old children. Marking of tyre was found on body. It is an example of -
exp: the synopsis for forensic medicine & toxicology, Dr. k. s. narayan reddy, 28th edition. Pg no. 108 Patterned bruising is also seen in motor car accident. Here the rickshaw tyre can produce patterned bruise on the body of the child.

question: Laceration shows all the features except:
exp: - There is lesser bleeding in case of lacerations because of crushing of the blood vessels. - General Features of Laceration: Irregular Shape Irregular & uneven Margins Contused edges Floor of laceration shows following features: - Tissue bridges (tissue, blood vessels and nerves bridging across the gap of the wound) - Less hemorrhage because of crushed blood vessels. - Foreign paicles like mud may be seen embedded in the wound, which gives clue about the scene of crime

question: Feelers strokes are also called as by all except
exp: - PRESENCE OF BEVELLED MARGIN INDICATES THAT THE WOUND IS HOMICIDAL IN NATURE - Synonyms of Hesitation cuts: Feelers strokes, Exploratory cuts & Tentative cuts. - Bevel: A surface having a sloped or slanting edge. Presence of a beveled margin indicates: i. Sharp cutting heavy or moderately heavy weapon was used. ii. Injury has been inflicted by striking the blade of the weapon. The chances of beveled margin by drawing or sawing the weapon are almost negligible. iii. Wound is homicidal in nature. iv. Direction of application of the weapon, and the relative position of assailant and the victim.

question: All of the following are included in grievous injury/hu except -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no. 154& 155; Abrasion on face will not be a permanent disfiguration of face, hence not grievous hu, all the other comes under grievous hu.

question: If a person keeps a man under his power and threatens him to cause harm without any intention to kill comes under which section of IPC -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no. 155; It is an assault coming under S. 351, I. P. C

question: Battle sign -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no. 107; A bruise behind the ear may indicate a basal fracture rather than a direct blow behind the ear. (BATTLE 'S SIGN) It is an example of ectopic bruising or percolated contusion.

question: Penetrating injury to NECK is defined as -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no. 114; A penetration wound is produced when the weapon enters a cavity of body. In penetrating injury to neck there is violation of platysma.
opb: Injury to any internal neck organ

question: In deep incised wounds, langer's lines determine -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s. narayan reddy; 28th edition; Pg. no. 116 The pattern of fibre arrangement of dense network of intimately intermingled dermal collagen & elastic fiber is called the cleavage direction or lines of cleavage of skin & their linear representation on the skin are called "Langer's line ", which are almost same in all person. A deep incised wound which cuts through cleavage lines transversely or obliquely will gap. Also refer Pg. no. 112

question: Backening of eye most common because of -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr. k. s. narayan reddy; 28th edition; Pg no. 107 Area around the eye is very delicate, hence blackening of eye is most commonly due to contusion. Also called spectacle hematoma. It is caused due to direct trauma, such as a punch in the eye or blunt impact to the forehead, the blood gravitating downwards over the supra orbital bridge or due to the fracture of the floor of the anterior fossa of the skull.

question: Extensive abrasions are found all over the body of a pedestrian lying by the road side. What is the likely cause?
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg, no. 148 There is extensive abrasion all over the body of the victim more over the victim was a pedestrian so it may be caused by striking the ground, rather than the vehicle itself hence it must be a secondary injury.

question: Which is not a feature of suicidal cut throat wound
exp: Defence wounds is a feature of homicidal wounds Suicidal cut throat wounds Usually stas from left side of neck, above downwards, ragged edges, may be multiple Hesitation cuts, tailing, cadaveric spasm with weapon may be present on hand

question: A completely charred body was brought for autopsy. You are examining the skull and cranial cavity. You find that there is a collection of blood in the epidural space. The presence of which of the following suggest the possibility of hematoma due to trauma:
exp: Epidural hematoma (EDH) due to burns and blunt force (trauma) EDH due to trauma EDH due to burns( Heat hematoma) Cause Blunt force to the head Charring of the skull due to intense heat Situation adjacent to Syln fissure Anywhere Position unilateral Usually bilateral Characteristics Disc shaped, smooth, uniform, rubbery, reddish-purple in colour honeycomb appearance; granular, friable clot; chocolate brown in color Skull fracture Fracture line radiating from a skull defect present in temporal area circular defect without radiating fracture lines, seen above the temple Crossing of suture lines Hematoma do not cross sutures It may cross suture lines
opc: Radiating Fracture lines over the skull

question: Harakiri is death by -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s. narayan reddy; 28th edition; Pg. no. 119 It is a unusual type of suicide, in whichthe victim inflicts a single large wound on the abdomen with a sho sword while in a sitting position or falls forward upon ceremonial sword & pulls out intestine. the sudden evisceration of internal organ causes sudden decrease of intra abdominal pressure & cardiac return, producing sudden cardiac collapse.
opd: Stab in the wrist plus neck

question: Patterened bruice is seen on -
exp: the synopsis for forensic medicine & toxicology, Dr. k. s narayan reddy, 28th edition. Pg no. 107 A patterned bruise is one in which the size and shape, mirror a poion of object which caused it. So it can occur on any pa of the body. The pattern gives the idea of the type of the weapon used, it connects the victim and the object or weapon.

question: Blue color of contusion seen at
exp: The age of contusion Time since injury color change first day red(Hb) 2-3 days blue(deoxy. Hb) 4-5 days bluish black/brown(hemosiderin) 5-6 days greenish(hematoidin) 7-10days yellow(bilirubin) By 14 days normal ref: FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY Dr PC IGNATIUS THIRD EDITION PAGE NO 118

question: Primary impact injury is most common in -
exp: the synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no. 148 In primary impact injury the pa of body involved depends upon the position of person in relation to vehicle struck & it is mostly seen on leg.

question: Gunshot residue on hands can be detected by -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no. 136 Paraffin test or dermal nitrate test is done to detect nitrates and nitrites. Melted paraffin is brushed on hand, the wax is removed & the inner surface of wax cast treated with diphenylamine or diphenylbenzedine reagent, a blue colour developes where residue is present, but it is obsolete.

question: Incisional wound on genital is seen commonly in -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; Pg. no 113; Incised wounds on nose, ear, genitals are usually homicidal & are inflicted on account of jealousy or revenge ( in case of adultery ) causing disfiguration.

question: The healing contusion shows green color due to the presence of:
exp: COLOR CHANGE PRESENCE OF AGING of contusion RED OXY-HEMOGLOBIN FEW HOURS BLUE DEOXY-HEMOGLOBIN FEW HOURS-3 DAYS BROWN HEMOSIDERIN 4-5 DAYS GREEN BILIVERDIN 6-7 DAYS YELLOW BILIRUBIN 7-12 DAYS

question: In which pa of body a lesser impact causes maximum bruise?
exp: the synopsis for forensic medicine& ttoxicology - Dr k. s. narayan reddy, 28 edition. Pg no. 106 If the pa is vascular & loose such as face, vulva, scrotum, a slight degree of violence may cause large bruise. Bruising is more marked on tissue overlying bone which acts as anvil, with the skin between the bone and inflicting force. Chronic alcoholic bruise easily. Abdomen, back, scalp, palms & soles, a blow of moderate violence produces comparatively small bruise due to firm fibrous tissue & covered by thick dermis.

question: In stab wounds, Langer's lines determine:
exp: CLEAVAGE LINES OF LANGER The pattern of collagen fiber arrangement are the lines of cleavage of the skin and their linear representations on the skin are known as "Langer's line of cleavage". A stab wound with long axis at right angles to the cleavage lines of Langer, will gape more. * A stab injury that runs parallel to these lines will gape less.

question: What is the age of abrasion?
exp: Scab has amost completely peeled off which indicates age >7 days Healing of Abrasion Fresh: Reddish in colour By 12- 24 hrs: Reddish Scab is formed (the scab formation occurs due to drying of superficial blood and lymph) By 2-3 days: Reddish brown scab By 4-7 days: Dark brown scab is formed, Epithelium grows under the scab and eventually. Scab stas falling off from margins After 7 days: Scab falls off leaving a depigmented area; later becomes pigmented.

question: Plaque Jaunes seen in -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no. 141; Plaque jaunes is seen in old healed coical contusion. contusions found in deeper structure of the brain along the line of impact are called intermediary coup contusion. Contusion caused by fracture of skull are called fracture contusion. Contusion in the coex & white matter of frontal & central convolution are called gliding contusion.

question: Double based smokeless gun powder consist of -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; Pg. no. 125 Nitrocellulose -single base Nitrocellulose & nitroglycerin - double base Nitrocellulose, nitroglycerin, nitroguanidine - triple base

question: In an incised wound, all of the following are true, except:
exp: Incised wound/ cut/ slash/ slice Margins clean cut & regular Blood vessels are clean cut, profuse bleeding present. Gaping is present & eversion of margins Tailing is present, suggesting the direction. Bevellingis seen if the blade cuts obliquely. POINTS TO REMEMBER:- CHARACTERS LACERATION INCISED WOUND Margins Irregular, edges contused Clean cut, regular Tissue bridges Present Absent Tailing Absent Present Bleeding Less (due to crushing of vessels) More (due to cutting of vessels)
opb: Bleeding is generally less than in lacerations
opd: Length of injury does not correspond with length of blade

question: Puppe's rule is associated with?
exp: Puppe's rule is associated with multiple impact injuries. PUPPE'S RULE It states that when two fracture lines intersect each other, the second fracture line never crosses the first one. It tells us the sequence of shots when multiple bullets have struck the skull, and it is also applicable to the multiple blunt impacts on the skull.

question: Which of the following skull fractures is called a 'motorcyclist's fracture' -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no. 151 In motorcyclist 's fracture the fracture is seen at the base of the skull, the base of skull is divided into two halves, and each moves like a hinge.
opa: Ring fracture of base of skull
opb: Hinge fracture of base of skull

question: Incised looking laceration is seen at?
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s. narayan reddy; 28th edition; Pg. no. 110 Blunt force on areas where the skin is close to bone, and the subcutaneous tissues are scanty, may produce a wound that looks like a incised wound. In the options given forehead is the most applicable answer as it fulfils all the required condition to produce a incised looking wound.

question: Shallow tails are seen in
exp: - Shallow tails: Tearing at the ends of lacerations at angles diverging from the main laceration - Tailing is different and is a feature of incised wound Tissue tags - Pieces of tissue are attached in between the edges.

question: Punch drunk syndrome is seen in -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no. 151. Punch drunk sign also called boxer's hemorrhage, head is frequently injured in boxers, fracture of skull is rare but subdural hemorrhage occurs and may be fatal, some show pontine hemorrhage. Bleeding into midbrain is seen. Retinal detachment may occur. Deterioration of speed &coordination are chief symptom of punch drunk(traumatic encephalopathy or dementia puglistica)condition.

question: One of the following structure is intact in closed head injury?
exp: Closed head injury (non-penetrating): Damage to the brain without any fracture of the skull and/or penetration of dura; most often results from blunt trauma. Ref - Krishan Vij textbook of forensic medicine and toxicology 5e pg: 281, 284

question: Black scab is formed at
exp: Age of abrasion Less than 24 hours bright red - reddish scab 2-3 days reddish- brown scab 4-5 days dark brown scab 6-7 days black scab ref: FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY Dr PC IGNATIUS THIRD EDITION PAGE 114

question: True about incised looking wounds are all, except:
exp: Incised looking laceration: Laceration looking like an incised wound (margins appears to be regular & clean cut) It is a type of split laceration wound Sites: Scalp, shin, eyebrows, cheek bones, iliac crest, knee & perineum. Avulsion laceration: Also called as Shearing laceration Run over injuries. Eg: Lorry wheel passes over a limb. Flapping/ Flaying: Direction of flap - direction of force.
opb: Avulsion lacerated wound with blunt object

question: The maximal increase of free histamine content occurs within how much time after injury
exp: The maximal increase of free histamine content occurs within 20 -30 minutes after injury. Biochemical timing of injury: It depends upon the measurement of histamine and serotonin contents of the injured tissue. Serotonin becomes maximum in about 10 min and histamine in 20-30 min after wounding. If the stroma is damaged, tissue cathepsins increase immediately, can be demonstrated within 5 to 10 minutes Postmoem wounds do not show any increase.

question: A case of murder with gunshot is repoed. A metal bullet is recovered from the body. Primary and secondary marking on a metal bullet can be used for -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no. 135 The firearm leaves their signature on the caridge case & on the bullet. With all rifled firearm the bullet is slightly larger than the barrel & as it passes through the barrel, its sides are marked by the rifling of the barrel (PRIMARY MARKINGS ). They are mist useful in identifying the make & model of gun involved. The surface of the bullet is also grooved by irregularities on the inner surface of the barrel itself (SECONDARY MARKINGS) which are specific for that paicular weapon.
opb: To know the range of firing

question: The inflicted weapon should be
exp: - The stab injury shows acute angles at both ends, which are suggestive of double edged weapon. If a double edged weapon is used, the wound will be elliptical or slit-like and both angles will besharp or pointed. If the knife penetrates to full length up to the guard, one or both edges maybe blunt. - In case of single edged knife wound is wedge shaped sometimes blunt edge of knife can harm the skin giving it a tail like appearance which is known as FISH TAIL. -In case of screwdriver the wound is slit-like with squared ends and abraded margins. - In case of ice pick the wound is circular in shape

question: A woman assaulted by neighbour was brought to you in the emergency depament with fractures of middle tooth. Injury was extended medially to the mouth and there was also contusion to bilateral leg. What is the nature of this injury?
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no. 155; As there is fracture of tooth, injury extending medially to mouth &contusion on leg which causes severe body pain, it is a grievous hu.

question: Which vehicular injury is not caused by direct contact of vehicle -
exp: the synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no. 149 Direct contact of the vehicle produces primary impact injury, secondary impact injury is also caused by the impact of the vehicle but the secondary injury is caused by the victim's striking object, such as the ground.

question: Antemoem bruise is differentiated from postmoem bruise by:
exp: Extravasation of blood into surrounding tissues is a characteristic feature of antemoem bruise.
opb: Capillary rupture with extravasation of blood

question: What is true about antemoem wound? -
exp: the synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no. 105; Aerial bleeding is present in antemoem wound, all the other features are wrong regarding antemoem wound.

question: Most common organ involved in air blast injury is -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no. 138 The tympanic membrane rupture most commonly with hemorrhage in ear.

question: Which of the following is not abrasion -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no. 111 & 104 Avulsion is a type of laceration also called flaying.

question: Punishment for voluntary causing Grevious hu comes under -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no. 155; Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hu comes under S. 325, I. P. C-imprisonment up to 7 years & also fine.

question: Brown color of contusion is due to:
exp: Color Pigment Time Duration Red Oxy hemoglobin Fresh Blue Deoxy hemoglobin Few hours - 3 days Brown Hemosiderin 4 -5 days Green Biliverdin/ hematoidin 6 -7 days Yellow Bilirubin 7 - 14 days

question: Injury caused by pedestrian in a vehicular accident due to striking to the object on road is known as -
exp: the synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no. 148. Injury caused by the victim's striking object such as the ground comes under secondary injury.

question: Second injury is an explosion is due to -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no. 138 The blast may drive multiple fragments of bomb or pieces of nearby objects, e. g gravel, glass, wood, brick, plaster etc through the air into the skin & causes bruises, abrasion, puncture lacerations intimately mixed on skin.

question: All among the following are characteristics of postmoem abrasions except
exp: Source Ante moem wounds Post-moem wounds Site Anywhere on the body Usually over bony prominences Colour Bright reddish brown Yellowish, translucent, Parchment like Exudation More; scab slightly raised Less; scab often lies slightly below the level of skin Microscopic Intravital reaction and congestion seen No intravital reaction No congestion
opa: Exudation is more and scab is slightly raised

question: Tear drop appearance seen in
exp: Stab wound by single edged weapon wedge shaped with one end of the wound is sharply cut and the other end is split or rounded or blunt. The sharp end is due to the contact with the sharp edge of the weapon and split end is due to contact with the blunt edge of the weapon. There may be gaping of both margins and this may give the wound a tear drop appearance ref: FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY Dr PC IGNATIUS THIRD EDITION PAGE 127
opa: Incised wound by single edged weapon
opb: Incised wound by double edged weapon
opc: Stab wound by single edged waeapon
opd: Stab wound by double edged weapon

question: In a case of hanging, ligature mark is an example of:
exp: LIGATURE MARK IN CASE OF HANGING IS AN EXAMPLE OF PRESSURE ABRASION Pressure abrasions are caused by crushing of the superficial layers of the epidermis Causative forces: Pressure abrasion: Ligature mark in hanging & strangulation Scratch abrasion: Fingernails, pin, thorn, tip of a knife Graze abrasion: Road traffic accidents Patterned abrasion: Tyre marks, Ligature mark.

question: In which of the following weapons, empty caridge case is ejected after firing -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no 124 In a pistol when a caridge is fired the empty caridge case is thrown out & a new caridge slips into the breech by a spring.

question: Graze is a type of -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no. 105 Grazes (sliding, scrapping or grinding abrasion) they occur when there is horizontal or near horizontal movement between the skin & some rough surface in contact with it.

question: A clean incised wound heals by -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine &toxicology.; Dr k. s. narayan reddy; 28 th edition; Pg. no. 113 A clean incised wound heals by primary intention. the steps are: Few minutes - dilatation of capillaries & margination & emigration of neutrophils, reactive changes in the tissue histiocytes& swelling of vascular endothelium. 12 hours - reactive changes occur in the fibroblasts at the site of injury within few hours; monocytes appear in exudate. 15 hours - monocytes begin to undergo mitotic division. 24 hours - epithelium begins to grow at the edges. Vascular bud begin to form. 72 hours - vascularized granulation tissue is formed. 4-5 days - new fibrils are formed. 1 week - scar formation in small wound.

question: "Undeaker's fracture" is commonly seen in:
exp: Undeaker's fracture is basically a postmoem fracture, and occurs due to careless handling of the dead body by undeakers; in fact this fracture can be produced by anyone who has to do anything with the dead body. Pathologists are known to extend the head to make the removal of the neck structures easier. To do this, they usually inse a block about 10-15 cm high under the neck may fall forcibly backwards, producing this fracture. It involves subluxation of the lower cervical spine due to tearing of the interveebral disc at about C6-C7

question: Waddell's triad of injuries is seen in:
exp: Waddell's triad - It is a pattern of injury seen in pedestrian children who are struck by motor vehicles. - It comprises of fractured femoral shaft, intra-thoracic/intra-abdominal injuries and contralateral head injury. - Mechanism of injury is an initial impact causing injury to the pelvis and femur instead of the knees and tibia followed by the chest and abdomen (grill, fender or hood). - Then the child is thrown on the ground and sustaining injury to the opposite side of the head
opa: Adult pedestrian struck by motor vehicles
opb: Pediatric pedestrian struck by motor vehicles
opc: Front seat passengers of motor vehicles

question: Flaying is seen in which type of lacerated wound:
exp: Avulsion laceration: Also called as Shearing laceration due to run-over injuries. Eg: lorry wheel passes over a limb. Flapping/ Flaying: A flap of tissues is stripped off from the underlying bone. Direction of flap - direction of force.

question: Shotgun does not contain -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no. 122 A shot gun have a muzzle, barrels, choke bore but not a bullet.

question: A person breaks someone's mandible in alleged fight. Police can -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no. 155; Breaking of mandible comes under grievous hu, so the police can arrest the the person who caused the hu without a warrant.
opc: Declares him hostile and out him in jail

question: Not a grievous hu -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no. 154&155; All except option 2 comes under grievous hu, contusion over the scalp is a minor injury and doesn't come under grievous hu.

question: Length of stab gives information about -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; Pg. no. 114: The length of the wound is slightly less than the width of the weapon upto which it has been driven in, because of the stretching of the skin. Therefore length of stab wound gives information of the width of the weapon.

question: Most common organ affected in underwater blast -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no. 138 The physical changes are similar to those of explosion in air. injuries occurs mostly in git & less common in lungs.

question: Destructive power of bullet is determined by -
exp: the synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no 130 The fatality is determined by the velocity of the bullet, the more its velocity the more will be its penetrating power, & more will be chance to cause fatality.

question: Blue color of the bruise is due to -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine &toxicology. Dr k. s. narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no. 108; Blue colour of the bruise which develops in 5-6 days is due to haemtoidin.

question: Blackening of eye after forehead injury is due to:
exp: Ectopic bruise/ Migratory bruise: Appearance of Bruise at a site other than the site of impact. Blood tracks along fascial planes or between muscle layers along the path of least resistance and then may appear where the tissue layers become superficial. Site of bruise does not always indicate the site of injury Site of Impact Bruising site Forehead Periorbital (Black eye/ spectacle hematoma/ Racoon eye) Iliac crest Lateral aspect of thigh Calf muscle Behind tendo-calcaneum

question: Hu includes all except -
exp: the synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no. 154. Hu means bodily pain, disease or infirmity caused to any person.

question: Black gun powder composition -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; Pg. no. 125 Fine grains travel 60cm or more, one gram of powder produces 3, 000-4, 500c. c of gas

question: A person 'X' hits another person 'y' with a wooden stick on provocation. This leads to formation of a bruise 3cm x 3 on the forearm. No other injuries are noted. Which of the following is true, regarding his punishment -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no. 155; It is voluntary cause of hu, so under S. 323, I. P. C. imprisonment up to one year or with fine or both.
opa: Imprisonment for one year and\/or fine of Rs. 1000
opb: Imprisonment for two year and\/or fine of Rs. 5000
opc: Imprisonment for 1 month and \/or fine of Rs. 500

question: All are true about antemoem contusion except -
exp: The synopsis for forensic medicine & toxicology, Dr k. s. narayan reddy, 28th edition; Pg no. 108; In antemoem bruising, there is swelling, damage to epithelium, extravasation, coagulation & infiltration of tissue with blood & colour changes. these points are absent in postmoem bruises. Hence it is seen that there will b swelling & inflammation in antemoem bruises. No inflammation in antemoem bruise is a wrong statement.

question: Whiplash injury of spine is due to
exp: Whiplash injury This injury classically occurs in an occupant of a vehicle due to sudden acceleration which causes sudden extension followed by flexion. There may be fracture dislocation of cervical veebrae. Both accrleaccele and deceleration injuries are included in the category of whiplash injury. Hyperextension injuries are common. Whiplash injuries are common in front seat occupants. Ref: FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY DR PC IGNATIUS THIRD EDITION PAGE 178

question: Which is true about stab wound -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; Pg. no. 116; In a stab wound the depth ( length of track ) is greater than the width & length of external injury, the depth of a stab wound is usually equal to or less than length of blade, that is used in producing it, but in anterior abdominal wall depth of wound is greater due to the force of thrust that may press the tissue underneath.
opd: It has wound of entry and exit

question: Stellate wound may be seen in which of the following bullet entry wounds -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no 130 In a contact shot the muzzle blast & the negative pressure in the barrel following discharge may suck blood, hair fragments, tissue, cloth fibers several cm. Back inside the barrel called back spatter. back spatter is more common with shotgun. The discharge from muzzle i. e gases, flames, powder, smoke & mettalic paicles are blown into the track taken by bullet through the body. the wound is large, triangular, stellate, cruciate, elliptical showing cavitations.

question: Calibre is defined as -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; Pg. no. 122 It is also called gauge. Also refer fig 8-16 (cross section of a rifled barrel)
opa: Distance between two diametrically opposite grooves
opb: Distance between two diametrically opposite lands
opc: Distance between two diametrically opposite lands and grooves
opd: Ratio of the length and width of the barrel

question: Flaying is seen in which type of laceration -
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s. narayan reddy; 28th edition; Pg. no. 110 & 111. Flaying comes under avulsion. The shearing & grinding force by a weight, such as lorry wheel passing over a limb, may produce seperation of skin from underlying tissue (avulsion ) over a relatively large area. This is called "FLAYING". The underlying muscles are crushed and the bones are fractured.

question: Difference between contusion and post-moem lividity is that post-moem lividity-
exp: The synopsis of forensic medicine & toxicology; Dr k. s narayan reddy; 28th edition; pg. no. 88; Contusion or bruises are not washable but postmoem lividity is washable. Also refer page no. 106
